Question_1.Context: The study investigated the production of lignin-derived products from steam-exploded palm oil mill lignocellulosic biomass waste (POMLBW).
Question_1.Question: What is the main purpose of the study?
Question_1.A: To evaluate the thermal characteristics of lignin-derived products
Question_1.B: To investigate the antioxidant activities of lignin-derived products
Question_1.C: To analyze the antimicrobial properties of lignin-derived products
Question_1.D: To study the molecular weight of lignin-derived products
Question_1.Source: LML from all steam-exploded POMLBW have antimicrobial properties against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria.

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the antioxidant activity of lignin-derived products using the DPPH free radical scavenging assay.
Question_2.Question: How was the antioxidant activity of lignin-derived products assessed?
Question_2.Source: The antioxidant activity was evaluated by measuring hydrogen/electron donation ability using 0.5 mM 2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl (DPPH) free radical scavenging assay.

Question_3.Context: The study investigated the production of lignin-derived products from agricultural biomass waste via steam explosion pretreatment.
Question_3.Question: What method was used to extract lignin-derived products?
Question_3.Source: The steam-exploded POMLBW was extracted using 60 mL/g distilled water for 24 h at room temperature; the water-soluble-derived lignin (WSL) was then filtered using filter paper no. 131.

Question_4.Context: The study evaluated the thermal behavior of lignin-derived products using differential scanning calorimetry.
Question_4.Question: What is the glass transition temperature (Tg) of lignin-derived products from EFB 35/5?
Question_4.Source: EFB 35/5 showed the lowest Tg at 47 °C.

Question_5.Context: The study assessed the antimicrobial activities of lignin-derived products using agar diffusion assays.
Question_5.Question: Which bacteria showed the highest inhibition zone by LML from KS 35/5?
Question_5.Source: LML in all steam-exploded EFB, KF, and KS inhibited S. enterica with an approximately 0.4 cm inhibition zone.

Question_6.Context: The study analyzed the thermal decomposition of lignin-derived products using thermogravimetric analysis.
Question_6.Question: What is the temperature at which the samples start losing mass (Ts) for LML KS 40/5?

Question_7.Context: The study investigated the polyphenol content and antioxidant activity of lignin-derived products.
Question_7.Question: Which severity factor resulted in the highest polyphenol amount in WSL from EFB?
Question_7.Source: EFB 40/5 produced the highest amount of polyphenols.

Question_8.Context: The study evaluated the molecular weight of lignin-derived products using gel permeation chromatography.
Question_8.Question: What was the average molecular weight of LML from KF 35/5?
Question_8.Source: The LML from KF 35/5 had an average molecular weight between 2769 and 1840 Da.

Question_9.Context: The study assessed the polyphenol content of lignin-derived products using the Folin–Ciocalteu method.
Question_9.Question: Which condition resulted in the lowest EC50 value for LML from EFB?
Question_9.Source: The highest RSA value of the LML steam-exploded EFB was found at 40/5, which also had a low EC50 value.

Question_10.Context: The study investigated the antimicrobial activities of lignin-derived products using agar diffusion assays.
Question_10.Question: Which bacteria showed the lowest inhibition zone by LML from KF 40/5?
Question_10.Source: The smallest inhibition zone was observed for the KS 45/10 pretreatment.
